channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Reacts to Donald Trump’s Win in U.S. Presidential Election
item.description: Donald J. Trump has said he would transform America’s relationship with allies and adversaries. He has pledged to end the war in Ukraine in 24 hours, increase tariffs and deport millions.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave and Catherine Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Richard A. Brooks/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Watching news of the U.S. presidential election in Tokyo on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump Victory Will Signal a Shift in Ukraine War. To What Is Unclear.
item.description: As U.S. president, Donald J. Trump will inherit a role as Ukraine’s chief benefactor. But he has been skeptical about continuing aid to Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Siversk, eastern Ukraine. The city has been under heavy shelling from Russian-occupied territory.

item.title: Live Updates: Israelis Protest Firing of Defense Minister
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s dismissal of Yoav Gallant was seen as a risky step as Israel fights wars on two fronts. Opposition leaders said the move put national security at risk.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: By Firing Gallant, Netanyahu Removes One Threat but Risks Another
item.description: Yoav Gallant, the departing defense minister, had opposed Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on key policies. His dismissal removes an opponent but has stirred public discontent.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Yoav Gallant saluting as a sign of respect to Israel’s security forces at the end of a news conference in Tel Aviv on Tuesday.

item.title: Tiny Homes Face the Ax in Hong Kong, Leaving Many Families Worried
item.description: The government says the city’s smallest apartments need more regulation. For some of Hong Kong’s poorest, that could mean higher rents or even eviction.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Billy H.C. Kwok for The New York Times
item.media:description: Liu Lanhua in her subdivided apartment in the Kwun Tong district of Hong Kong. Such homes are among the starkest examples of the city’s vast income inequality.

item.title: How Kemi Badenoch Became Leader of the UK Conservative Party
item.description: Kemi Badenoch’s ascent is partly the result of a deliberate diversifying of the party under David Cameron in the 2000s. In her politics, she exemplifies its more recent rightward turn.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Kemi Badenoch, center, following her election as leader of the Conservative Party in London on Saturday.

item.title: Russian Plot Placed Incendiary Devices on Cargo Planes in Europe, Officials Say
item.description: Western officials are investigating whether devices planted at shipping hubs in Europe may have been a test run by Russian operatives for placing them on planes bound for the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: A DHL airplane at the Leipzig/Halle Airport, Germany, in October. Incendiary devices were planted this summer at DHL shipping hubs in Leipzig and Birmingham, England, Western officials said.

item.title: Facing Outrage, Nigeria Drops Capital Charges Against Minors
item.description: Dozens of teenagers had been accused of treason and faced possible death sentences, but indignation over their treatment, including lack of food, has the government backpedaling.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Ismail Auwal
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: People run away from tear gas during a protest on the street in Kano, Nigeria, in August.

item.title: Irish Leader Plans to Call Election Later This Week
item.description: Simon Harris, Ireland’s prime minister, said Tuesday that he would dissolve Parliament later this week, setting the stage for a general election by the end of the month.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Simon Harris, prime minister of Ireland, after meeting with President Biden at the White House in October.

item.title: Who Is Israel Katz, Israel’s New Defense Minister?
item.description: The prime minister has replaced an experienced former general with Mr. Katz, who had been foreign minister and who has staunchly supported Israel’s right-wing government.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:credit: Brittainy Newman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israel Katz addressing the United Nations General Assembly in 2019, during an earlier stint as Israel’s foreign minister. He was named defense minister on Tuesday.

item.title: After Spain’s Deadly Floods, Search for the Missing Grows Desperate
item.description: A week after catastrophic floods, some families are unsure if their relatives are alive. Late on Tuesday, the government said that 89 people were missing in a provisional count.
item.dc:creator: José Bautista and Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: The Torre neighborhood of Valencia, Spain, on Thursday. In the wake of the flooding, social media pages have lit up with pictures of the disappeared.

item.title: U.K. Confirms New Cases of Clade Ib Type of Mpox
item.description: The authorities said the risk of a rapid spread remained low because the new cases had had household contact with the first infected person.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.category: European Center for Disease Prevention and Control
item.media:credit: Sam Bush for The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside St Thomas’ Hospital, one of the London hospitals treating the people who contracted mpox.

item.title: UK’s Queen Camilla Cancels Royal Engagements Because of Illness
item.description: Buckingham Palace said Camilla, 77, was unwell with a chest infection and had been advised to rest.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Camilla, Queen Consort of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Britain’s Queen Camilla waves from a car as she leaves an engagement in Bath, western England, in September.

item.title: Indonesian Tribe Adopts Korean Hangul to Preserve Ancient Cia-Cia Language
item.description: The Cia-Cia language has been passed down orally for centuries. Now the tribe’s children are learning to write it in Hangul, the Korean script.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono
item.media:credit: Nyimas Laula for The New York Times
item.media:description: Teaching Hangul, the Korean alphabet, to Cia-Cia children in Baubau, Indonesia. People trying to preserve the tribe’s spoken language found that the Korean script was a good fit for it.

item.title: Israeli Officials Embrace Trump Victory, Despite His Unpredictability
item.description: There is a belief in Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s right-wing Israeli government that a Trump administration will allow it to end its wars on favorable terms.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Supporters of Donald J. Trump gathering at a bar in Jerusalem to watch the reporting of U.S. election results on Wednesday.

item.title: Japan’s Mount Fuji Gets Snow After Breaking Snowless Record
item.description: Mount Fuji, the country’s tallest summit, is revered for its snowy peak. A snowfall reported on Wednesday ended its longest snowless period in 130 years.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Hisako Ueno
item.media:description: A sign with a photo of Mount Fuji, with the snowless mountain in the distance, last week.

item.title: Mexico’s Top Court Dismisses Proposal to Invalidate Judicial Overhaul
item.description: The move spares the country’s new president from having to choose between recognizing a court decision to strike down the overhaul or aligning with her party’s leaders and ignoring it.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Simon Romero
item.media:description: People holding photographs of the Supreme Court justices during a protest against a judicial reform law in Mexico City, on Tuesday.

item.title: Who Is Yoav Gallant?
item.description: The Israeli defense minister was fired by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel after the two clashed over the course of Israel’s war in the Gaza Strip.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:description: Yoav Gallant at Israel’s Ministry of Defense in Tel Aviv on Tuesday, after being fired by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

item.title: North Korea Enters Ukraine Fight for First Time, Officials Say
item.description: Western and Ukrainian officials have called the appearance of North Korean forces on the battlefield a major escalation.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: The North Korean Embassy in Moscow in October.

item.title: A Timeline of Clashes Between Netanyahu and Gallant, Israel’s Former Defense Minister
item.description: Yoav Gallant, the ousted cabinet minister, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, had sharp public disagreements over Israel’s war against Hamas and what will follow it.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, left, and Defense Minister Yoav Gallant at a news conference at Kirya military base in Tel Aviv, Israel, on Oct. 28, 2023, three weeks after the war with Hamas began.

item.title: Special Edition: America Votes
item.description: An anxious wait begins.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voters outside a museum in Michigan.

item.title: Lightning Strikes Soccer Team in Peru, Killing Player
item.description: A video of the incident shows a flash of light and then several players instantly dropping to the ground.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:description: A screengrab from a local broadcast in Peru on Sunday, when a soccer player died and four others were hospitalized after a lightning strike during a soccer game.

item.title: Netanyahu Fires Yoav Gallant, Israel’s Defense Minister
item.description: The minister, Yoav Gallant, differed with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu over the conduct of the war in Gaza and domestic political issues.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: Yoav Gallant, the Israeli defense minister fired by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, at a news conference on Tuesday.

item.title: Growing Food Instead of Lawns in California Front Yards
item.description: Front yards transformed to tiny crop farms in Los Angeles provide vegetables to dozens of families and use a fraction of the water needed by grass.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley and Alisha Jucevic
item.media:credit: Alisha Jucevic for The New York Times
item.media:description: Morgan Boone, a volunteer with Crop Swap LA, harvested lettuce at the La Salle Microfarm in the view View Park neighborhood of Los Angeles.

item.title: China Confronts Europe Over Climate-Based Trade Restrictions
item.description: Days ahead of the U.N.’s global negotiations on climate change, China and other developing countries said trade restrictions should be part of the talks.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: China-made vehicles ready for export in Shandong Province of China.

item.title: For Biden Officials, Lebanon May Be a Problem Too Big to Solve
item.description: Despite hopes that political shifts in Beirut could bring lasting peace to the Israel-Lebanon border, the United States may have to settle for a quicker fix.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Beirut on Oct. 19 after multiple Israeli airstrikes. Some senior U.S. officials have called Israel’s campaign against Hezbollah an opportunity to reshape the politics of Beirut and stand up a stronger Lebanese government, but others say that is a fanciful goal.

item.title: Gazans Fear Neither Candidate in U.S. Election Will Help Them
item.description: American politics have not been topmost in the minds of Gazans. “We only need one thing: for this war to come to an end,” one man said.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack, Bilal Shbair and Abu Bakr Bashir
item.media:description: The rubble of a destroyed house in Khan Younis in southern Gaza on Monday.

item.title: Israel Strikes Syria for Second Day, Targeting Hezbollah Weapons Facilities
item.description: The military said the attacks were meant to reduce the transfer of weapons and intelligence from Iran through Syria to Hezbollah, the armed group in Lebanon.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni and Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: A damaged building after an Israeli raid near Jenin in the West Bank on Tuesday.

item.title: Israeli or Palestinian, U.S. Voters in the West Bank Say Biden Let Them Down
item.description: Tens of thousands of U.S. citizens live in the Israeli-occupied territory, on opposing sides of an entrenched conflict, where neither Palestinians nor Israelis have much enthusiasm for Kamala Harris.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Isadora Kosofsky for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voters at the Italian-American Club in San Pedro, Calif., on Monday.

item.title: Whether Trump or Harris, Pessimism Reigns in Russia Over U.S. Election Winner
item.description: Russian officials feel disrespected by the Democrats and betrayed by Donald J. Trump, who lavished praise on President Vladimir V. Putin but made decisions the Kremlin saw as benefiting Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: An exhibition of captured military hardware from NATO countries in Moscow in May. Hope among Russians that either candidate in the U.S. presidential election will be able to end the war in Ukraine quickly is low.

item.title: Russian and Other Groups May Try to Undermine U.S. Elections After Vote
item.description: Groups from Russia and other countries could continue to stoke political discord until the election is certified in January, intelligence agencies say.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Steven Lee Myers
item.media:description: Early voting in Luzerne County, Pa., on Monday. Federal officials say foreign powers are likely to try to sow doubt about the election results no matter who wins.

item.title: Canada Announces Carbon Emission Caps for Oil and Gas Sectors
item.description: The Trudeau government has focused on the oil and gas production industries because the large amounts of energy they use make them the country’s largest source of greenhouse gases.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.category: Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs
item.media:description: An oil sands operations near Fort McMurray, Alberta. Oil sands are a production is a major source of carbon emissions.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Americans brace for Election Day
item.description: Plus, remembering Quincy Jones.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Bridget Bennett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Early voting in Las Vegas, Nevada.

item.title: Sydney to Become Seventh World Major Marathon in 2025
item.description: The Sydney Marathon has joined the ranks of New York, Boston, Chicago, London, Berlin and Tokyo, receiving a designation reserved for the most elite races in the world.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin
item.media:description: Participants during the 2024 Sydney Marathon in Sydney, Australia, in September. The finish line is at the Sydney Opera House.

item.title: Israeli Strikes Damage a Major Hospital in Northern Gaza, Officials Say
item.description: Patients and medical staff were wounded at Kamal Adwan Hospital, one of the few in northern Gaza still providing limited medical care, the health ministry and the hospital’s chief said.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: The area around Kamal Adwan Hospital, in northern Gaza, on Thursday after an Israeli offensive damaged or destroyed many buildings.

item.title: Iranians Wonder if Trump Wins, Would Things Be Different This Time?
item.description: While Donald J. Trump is seen by many in Tehran as having been disastrous for their country, some hope he might be more open to negotiation in a second term as U.S. president.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A reporter is looking at Shargh’s website and an article about U.S. elections in the newspaper’s offices in Tehran, Iran on Sunday.

item.title: Heavy Rains Hit Spain, Still Reeling From Deadly Flooding
item.description: Emergency workers continued the search for victims of last week’s flash floods, while a national debate raged over who was to blame for the catastrophe.
item.dc:creator: José Bautista and Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Cleanup efforts in Alfafar, Spain, on Monday. The municipality is in the Valencia region, which was hardest hit by last week’s flash floods.

item.title: Smog Will Shut Schools in Pakistan’s 2nd-Largest City for a Week
item.description: The city of Lahore reported hazardous levels of air pollution on Sunday. Pakistani officials have blamed India for some of it.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young and Salman Masood
item.media:description: Students wearing masks to school in Lahore on Monday. Primary schools in the city are being closed this week after the city reached record levels of air pollution.

item.title: Worker in Netanyahu Office Accused of Leaking Classified Documents in Israel: What to Know
item.description: An individual with connections to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s office is being investigated. Here’s what to know about how the furor began and what might happen next.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, left, and the country’s defense minister, Yoav Gallant, at an army base near Mitzpe Ramon, Israel, on Thursday.

item.title: In Northern Gaza, Staying and Evacuation Both Carry Deadly Risks
item.description: For Gazans facing Israel’s latest offensive against Hamas in the north, every option is fraught with peril.
item.dc:creator: Nader Ibrahim, Erika Solomon and Riley Mellen
item.media:description: Ramy Nasr and two of his daughters, Lamar, left, and Dana, about a month before the war started.

item.title: Trial Over Killing of Teacher Samuel Paty Begins in France
item.description: Eight more people are facing charges over the 2020 murder of the teacher, Samuel Paty, who had displayed caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad as an illustration of free speech.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:description: A courthouse in Paris on Monday where eight people went on trial in connection with the killing of Samuel Paty. The assailant was killed by the police.

item.title: At Least 10 Killed in Indonesia After Volcano Erupts
item.description: The authorities warned of more volcanic activity at Mount Lewotobi Laki-laki, which has erupted dozens of times in the past few weeks.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young and Hasya Nindita
item.media:description: Smoke billows from Mount Lewotobi Laki-laki as seen from Klatanlo village, in East Flores Regency, East Nusa Tenggara, on November 4, 2024, after it erupted overnight.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Nick Hagen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Early voting in Michigan on Sunday.

item.title: Pro-West Leader Wins High-Stakes Vote in Former Soviet Republic
item.description: The president of Moldova, Maia Sandu, won re-election on Sunday against a rival candidate she had denounced as “Moscow’s man.”
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Maia Sandu, who won re-election as Moldova’s president, celebrating the election runoff’s preliminary results in Moldova’s capital, Chisinau, on Sunday.

item.title: Monday Briefing: The Final Set of Times/Siena Election Polls
item.description: Plus, using generative A.I. to take a “decision holiday.”
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Doug Mills; Erin Schaff/The New York Times

item.title: An Iranian American Was Arrested in Iran, U.S. Confirms
item.description: Rights groups said that Reza Valizadeh, an Iranian-American journalist, was recently arrested in Iran, although the State Department did not confirm that he was the person detained.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators mark the 45th anniversary of Iran’s takeover of the U.S. embassy in Tehran.

item.title: Thousands of Children in Gaza Get 2nd Dose of Polio Vaccine
item.description: Aid agencies said that children in some areas of northern Gaza where Israel is mounting an offensive against Hamas will miss the doses, compromising the effectiveness of the campaign.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: Palestinian children arriving for their vaccinations at a hospital in Gaza City on Saturday.

item.title: Trump or Harris Victories Offer Different Futures for Ukraine
item.description: The presidential candidates have expressed starkly contrasting visions for America’s role in the war, as well as the NATO alliance that serves as a shield against Russian aggression.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine firing a howitzer at Russian positions in June.

item.title: A Lebanese Town Tries to Stay Out of Israel-Hezbollah War
item.description: While Lebanese are united against Israel’s onslaught, some in southern towns where Hezbollah does not hold sway say they feel caught between Israel’s firepower and Hezbollah’s fighters.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Hwaida Saad and David Guttenfelder
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A boy, displaced from his family’s border village home, playing in the courtyard of the Kfeir public high school in Hasbayya province, Lebanon, last month.

item.title: After Floods in Spain, Protesters Throw Mud at King Felipe VI and Officials
item.description: As the country reels from a flood that has left at least 214 people dead, thousands have flocked to devastated areas to help. Anger toward public officials is growing.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel, José Bautista and Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Volunteers sweep the mud from a street in the aftermath of the flooding, in Alfafar, near Valencia, Spain on Saturday.

item.title: Sikh Activists See It as Freedom. India Calls It Terrorism.
item.description: Canadian and U.S. accusations of assassination plots have drawn attention to the Sikh separatist movement, which India calls a source of organized crime.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das
item.media:credit: Jackie Dives for The New York Times
item.media:description: Khalistan flags last year in Surrey, British Columbia. India has repeatedly accused Khalistan-related activists in countries like Canada of sponsoring gang warfare, drug trafficking and extortion in India.

item.title: Polish Radio Station Uses A.I. to Interview Dead Nobel Laureate
item.description: A radio station in Poland fired its on-air talent and brought in A.I.-generated presenters. An outcry over a purported chat with a Nobel laureate quickly ended that experiment.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mariusz Marcin Pulit, who runs Radio Krakow and niche stations operating under its umbrella like Off Radio Krakow, said his only goal with the experiment was to revive a station that had few listeners.

item.title: Israel Says Elite Naval Commandos Abducted Hezbollah Operative
item.description: It appeared to be the deepest Israeli operation by sea and ground inside Lebanon during the current war.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward, Aaron Boxerman and Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:description: Lebanese soldiers on Saturday inspect the site where Israeli naval commandos are believed to have landed to abduct what Israel said was a Hezbollah operative in the coastal city of Batroun in northern Lebanon.

item.title: German Government at Risk of Collapse After Rift on Economy
item.description: A breakup of the divided and unpopular coalition well before elections set for next September could leave the country directionless at a critical time for Europe.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: The three key leaders of Germany’s coalition government, from left, Robert Habeck of the Greens, the economic minister; Chancellor Olaf Scholz of the Social Democrats; and Christian Lindner of the Free Democratic Party, the finance minister, in September.

item.title: COP16 Talks in Colombia Adopt a Novel Way to Pay for Conservation
item.description: Delegates at the U.N. talks created a system that would compensate countries for the use of genetic information but failed to make headway on a broader funding commitment.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.category: United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity
item.media:description: The talks, sponsored by the United Nations, were held in Cali, Colombia.

item.title: Kemi Badenoch, New Leader of the U.K.’s Tories, Vows to Make the Party More Conservative
item.description: Ms. Badenoch is expected to move the party, now in the opposition, further to the right.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle

item.title: Amid Flood Cleanup in Spain, Residents Try to Make Sense of the Disaster
item.description: Some see the floods as an example of the effect of a changing climate that is making overwhelming downpours more common. Locals also say government warnings came too late.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: A general view of the area affected by floods in Chiva, Spain, on Friday.
